CACTUS spectrometer -48 array of 28
high-efficiency lead-collimated NaI detectors arranged
in a spherical geometry.The total detection efficiency
of CACTUS is approximately 15% with each cylindrical
NaI detector of diameter 12.35 cm and 12.35 cm length,
the front face being situated 22 cm from the central
target position. For gamma-ray detection.
The response matrix for the CACTUS array was found by
performing detailed MCNP5 simulations of the CACTUS
detectors, the Pb collimators, the target and frame,
the vacuum chamber, and the detector casings for many
different energies and then interpolating between them.
The response was broadened with a broadening function
to provide the correct NaI detector resolution.
Silicon Ring detector- for LCP emitted
at backward angles from the beam direction.
Consist of ring of eight wedge-shaped detector modules,
each with eight arced dE strips of 130 microm thickness
placed in front of a single E detector of 1550 microm
thickness. The eight annular rings of the silicon
detectors were at angles of 124 deg for the outermost
ring and 138 deg for the innermost, giving an angular
resolution for charged-particle detection of slightly
less than 2 deg. The total solid angle covered by the
Silicon Ring was approximately 12% of 4PI sr.
An aluminum absorber of thickness 10.5 microm was
placed in front of the silicon detectors to block
electrons.
The energy resolution for detection of LCP assuming a
2-mm beam spot size was 80 keV.
For the (d,p) channel the best calibration coefficients
were obtained by using the elastic scattering peaks on
232Th(d,d') and 16O(d,d'), a target contaminant. For
the (3He,a) and (3He,t) channels the silicon detector
calibration coefficients were obtained from elastic
scattering peak of 232Th(3He,3He') and the position of
the 232Th(3He,a)231Th* ground state.
Systematic uncertainties in the measurement technique
due to effect of imperfect weighting functions owing
to the presence of gamma-detection thresholds and the
fact that the detectors do not have isolated hit
probability of 100% were estimated
-of the order 2% for relative (when comparing one
cross section with another) and
- 5% in the absolute value.
Oslo Cyclotron Laboratory using the
CACTUS and Silicon Ring detectors.
Beams of deuterium and 3He at bombarding energies of 1
2 and 24 MeV, respectively.
All coincidence events involving at least one
dE strip and at least one E detector were written to
disk along with any coincident gamma-ray data, if
present. During the 2 weeks of beam time (about 1 week
for d at 0.7 nA and 1 week for 3He at 0.4 nA) a total
of 351E+6 and 135E+6 dE-E coincidence events for d, and
3He beams, respectively, were recorded.
The final nucleus decay probabilities were measured
using the weighting function technique.

Weighting function technique.

968 microg/cm2 target of 232Th.
Radiative capture c-s deduced via the product
of measured gamma emission probability using the
transfer reaction Th-232(d,p)Th-233 .
The compound nucleus formation cross section was
obtained from TALYS optical model calculations with
input parameters adjusted to accurately reproduce the
experimental total cross sections.
Of compiler M.M. In title of Fig.9 in PR/C,85,034607
there is misprint in transfer reaction:
Th-233(d,p) instead of Th-232(d,p) .
In the range 500 keV-1 MeV there is very good agreement
with variations typically of the order of 15%.
Above 1 MeV the fission cross section begins to
increase and because we are unable to distinguish
events in which fission occurs, fission gamma rays will
begin to contaminate our spectra.
Above 1 MeV the surrogate data increasingly
overestimate the ENDFB7 database values.
The major discrepancy between our measurements and
ENDFB7 occur in the range 0-500 keV, where there is a
large and increasing disagreement toward low energy as
high as 400%.
This discrepancy probably occurs for two reasons:
1) the mismatch in spin distributions between the
indirect and direct reactions leading to an
overestimation of the cross section because decay of
higher final nuclear l waves favors decay by gamma
emission;
2) the finite resolution of silicon detectors smooths
out the step function at the neutron binding energy
that we are attempting to measure and thus the measured
decay probabilities are the most incorrect in this
region where the decay probability is varying extremely
rapidly.
Radiative capture c-s deduced via the product
of measured gamma emission probability using the
transfer reaction Th-232(He3,A)Th-231 .
The compound nucleus formation cross section was
obtained from TALYS optical model calculations with
input parameters identical to those for 232Th(n,gamma)
measurement (Subent 002).
Systematic errors (about 20%) owing to
introduction of the model-dependent compound nucleus
formation cross section.

Systematic errors (about 20%) owing to
